Message.Title: Derivatives Shifting
Message.Msg: Look at the tell signs on both the NASDAQ/NYSE. What is happening is stagnation in the major indices. This happens when the large derivative players are shifting their positions. They are now moving money and are going to bet against both markets. In the past this is when large corrections take place (over 10 percent). The large derivative players are the ones that run the indices. For example look at Warren Buffet; he is a heavy derivative player that has, over the last five years, substantially decreased his position in stocks and gone the derivative route. Smart, rich player. Derivative are an easy way to hide money.......so large losses can be covered up. The SEC does not understand this and they cannot track this. The result is no regulation. It will only take one major, dishonest derivative player to send our financial systems into ruin.

Topic.Title: Derivatives Shifting

Message.Msg: This seems to be a copy/paste of the last 5 identical threads you have started in the last 2 weeks. I would like some more detail to give this the weight you think it deserves. You say "look at the tell tale signs" .... what signs? You say "stagnation in the major indices" .... by what metric? You say this happens "when large derivative players are shifting their positions" ... how do you measure that? How can you tell they are "moving their money" so I can look for a cause and effect relationship you suggest? Warren Buffet plays derivatives through his insurance businesses but those are either reinsured or hedged. The credit default swaps clearinghouse does not show any unusual activity. What specifically are you looking at that makes you so fearful. Where, for example, do you think that Buffett is unhedged? I would like to do some DD on what you are saying but it makes no sense.

Topic.Title: Derivatives Shifting

Message.Msg: Let me approach it this way. About two years before the LIBOR manipulation became public, I bought this issue up to some friends in NY at a pool party. They did not take it seriousely. Well when the news broke some of them started listening closer, especially the investment banker.

Topic.Title: OMG!!! CHECK THIS OUT!!!!

Message.Msg: youtubeDOTcom/watch?v=mUsRXzmUDXw START WATCHING AT 3:40 This device is amazing. Here's how it works: 1) It is a note book when screen part is attached (runs windows 8) 2) it is a tablet when you pull the screen part out (runs Android) 3) when you pull screen part out, the keyboard has haswell inside!, so it becomes a desktop PC!!!! THIS IS GENIUS!!

Topic.Title: OMG!!! CHECK THIS OUT!!!!

Message.Msg: The screen part (tablet) has CloverTrail+ inside. This is a great product for Intel. For each unit sold, Intel sells 2 chips (Haswell + CloverTrail+)

Message.Title: ARM Holdings plc (ARM): Launch of new cores not enough to counter growing threat from Intel Corporation
Message.Msg: ARM Holdings plc (ARM): Launch of new cores not enough to counter growing threat from Intel Corporation warn analysts DetailsPublished on Monday, 03 June 2013 08:30 Written by Roberta Murray Shares in ARM Holdings plc (LON:ARM) are under pressure today; ARM is trading 1.86 pct in the red at 969.64 in morning trade. The weakness in ARM's performance chimes well with the Sell case on the stock maintained with analysts at Liberum Capital. ARM Holdings has launched new cores ARM has launched a new processor core, graphics core and video IP for the mid-range smartphone market. The ARM Cortex-A12 processor core falls between the previous generation Cortex A9 which powers most smartphones in the market today and the next generation high-end Cortex A15 processor which is beginning to come through in some high end devices. However, the base case at Liberum Capital is that Intel Corporation will continue to erode ARM's market-leading position. Analyst Janardan Menon says: "ARM expects to address the 580m mid-range smartphones that are expected to be sold in 2015 with the Cortex A12 which delivers 40% more performance than the Cortex A9 at the same level of power consumption. ARM has also launched the Mali-T622 graphics core targeted at the mid-range market along with the Mali V500 video IP solution. "This is the first time that ARM has launched video IP, a segment where Imagination already has a strong presence. On the processor core we do not expect the Cortex A12 to make a meaningful difference to ARM's outlook as ARM already has almost 100% market share in smartphones, covering the low, mid and high end of the market. "However Intel Corporation (NASDAQ:INTC) is attacking its share at both the mid and high-end of the market and the new core will help defend share at the mid-end. In graphics and video IP where Imagination is the leader, ARM's new products should continue to enable it to take further share. "We maintain our sell recommendation on ARM given its high

Topic.Title: Derivatives Shifting

Message.Msg: "look at Japan" Intentionally vague .... right? Whaling hunt capture/kill is at an all time low of 266 whales. Rice ball consumption is up 7.4% YoY. Those are "looking at Japan" but I think they are useless statistics. I will not trust what you say on good faith, no more than you should trust what I say. If you HAPPENED to be right, I will not be like your friends. I would expect that IF YOU HAPPENED TO BE RIGHT, it would be by accident and should carry no weight either. Nouriel Roubini predicted a low on the SP500 of 666 and showed his work in advance. SP500 bottomed at 666 and he became a God. Few people remember that when the SP500 dropped to 666, he lowered his target to 600. The market bounced. He is a very bright guy. I suspect much brighter than you or I. I expect you to offer reasons like your May 10th "SHORT MU" post when MU was $10.82 and now MU is trading at $11.90. I value a WRONG SHOWING YOUR WORK more than I do RIGHT NOT SHOWING YOUR WORK. The latter to me is a guest. If you want to show your work, I will listen. Since you have offered "derivatives" and "Japan", I will assume that your "perfect prediction" method has little to offer. Reply MU the perfect short for the following reasons:geraldmcginty by geraldmcginty • May 10, 2013 9:18 AM Flag 1. Unjustified runup in price 2. NASDAQ bubble 3. Hightly placed executives selling large amounts of stock in the mid-9s price range 4. 10 percent increase in short interest as of late Apr 5. Tecnology bubble with decreasing demand, lowest in 14 years 6. Derivative money now going against DOW/NASDAQ

Message.Title: Where are theCortex A15 ?
Message.Msg: ARM didn’t provide a list of the newcomers, but among the companies with a big.LITTLE license are names like MediaTek and HiSilicon. MediaTek are best known for the chipsets in mid-range smartphones from smaller companies and HiSilicon is behind Huawei’s custom chips. So, does the license mean cheap Cortex-A15/A7 chipsets are incoming? Here’s hoping it does – small makers have successfully challenged the big competitors (like Meizu MX 4-core outperforming Samsung Galaxy S III), but recently even big companies have started looking at MediaTek. Rumor has it that Sony is considering a phone based on a MediaTek quad Cortex-A7 CPU, now that ST-Ericsson (makers of NovaThor chipsets) is closed for business. Absent from the list are big players like Qualcomm, Apple and NVIDIA. Qualcomm and Apple design their own CPU cores rather than license a Cortex from ARM and NVIDIA has an analog of big.LITTLE with the 4-PLUS-1 architecture in the Tegra 3 and 4 chipsets, which explains the omissions. Other than Samsung, MediaTek and HiSilicon, Fujitsu Semiconductor, Renesas Mobile, CSR, LSI and Marvell have big.LITTLE licenses.

Message.Title: Intel has a good chance to take over the mobile market
Message.Msg: I am not an electrical engineer, I just like to spot trends and understand that technology platforms usually have an anchor that has most of the marketshare with others building around it, so it is a winner take all proposition usually, and I see Intel as being that leader in the near future. A few years ago, I was excited about ARM owning the mobile space. But it only took one insightful message to plant a seed of ARM's trouble and since then I have found numerous technical publications that confirmed this hypothesis: In 2011, on a niche message board, I read an electrical engineer discounting all the active computing power efficiency of ARM chips. His point was simple, but almost always over-looked by people just looking at the surface of what was happening: as chips get smaller, power leakage grows in proportion to active power usage in chips, therefore making active power consumption less and less of a driving force of total power consumption. So not, only does ARM have to fend off attacks as Intel chips become equal (and there are some reports it is equal to better now) in active power usage, but also deal with active power consumption become a minority in total power usage, a situation taking away ARM architecture's advantage. Intel on the other hand is peerless in chip fabrication and owning its own facilities ha much more direct control over manufacturing, so as chips become smaller, and transistors closer together, it seems little question that Intel will have a large advantage in dealing with that. So as that power loss becomes the majority of power consumption, Intel will take the lead, whether its chips match or exceed active power efficiency, with ARM, will become less and les s important. So reports it is catching up (or some reports exceeding) ARM in active power is only icing on the cake.

Message.Title: Chained Cannonballs
Message.Msg: Couple the Haswell & Silvermont release with the upcoming launch of 14nm and you have a bloody terrifying weapon cutting a destructive swath through the ARM ecosystem. The great advantage of a vertically integrated IDM is that you can trust intra-company communications. The design teams get accurate information from the manufacturing side and vice versa, but in a loose confederation of companies composing the ARM ecosystem, you have to wonder if the design companies can trust what the foundries are saying. And can they trust what ARM is saying? Take away trust and you take away everything. Add a well-armed adversary into the mix and you could end up with pandemonium and an ecosystem dissolving into bitter internal disputes. This could get gruesome.

Message.Title: Intel Inside Samsung Galaxy
Message.Msg: Intel inside Samsung Galaxy 3 Tab 10.1 was a foregone conclusion after rumors, turned unofficial news, over past few days. What I read today is the design win in 8.0 inch tablets too (not sure if true). I see this as a comprehensive design win for Intel rather than a trial by Samsung. And I see this as Samsung’s step towards boarding Bay Trail / Merrifield / Haswell trains when they arrive rather than achieving any immediate goal. There must be compelling reasons for Samsung to get onto Intel bandwagon. I think of following: 1. Lenovo-Intel partnership could take tablets/smartphones markets by storm with Bay Trail/Merrifield products (the same way Samsung taking market share from Apple), and Samsung would not like to be lagging even by a few months in that scenario. 2. Another trigger for the deal could be Intel’s announcement of New Devices group and associated speculation that Intel will make its own devices. 3. Apple’s iWatch project may actually be a strategy/cover/trial to switch over to Intel for iOS devices. 4. Samsung doesn’t want Qualcomm to grow stronger any further and be in a position to dictate terms. Though too early to say where all of above will go, these carry a potential of shifting market share among existing and new mobile players centered around Intel. Any business minded person/firm would be wise to have a risk mitigation plan – that includes getting onto Intel bandwagon. And Samsung is just doing that. I have argued previously (more than a year ago) that Apple as well as Samsung, despite their rivalry, both would like to avoid Intel as long as possible, for their own business reasons. But eventually one would go Intel and the other will have no choice but to follow. Well, Apple can continue its arrogance and keep on ignoring Intel in iPhones and iPads. But they will run a risk of looking silly down the line, particularly when Apple is no longer seen and felt as “Cool”.

Topic.Title: Intel Inside Samsung Galaxy

Message.Msg: Having said that, Intel should have Plan B of its own. It is possible that Samsung is using CT+ (may extend to BT) as a stop gap arrangement while it hopes to fix A15/big.LITTLE issues. Intel’s Plan B should make it impossible for Samsung to back off at a later stage. Intel’s Plan B could include continuing close partnership with Lenovo and other existing players and having its own New Devices group on standby (ready to enter markets if the partners falter) – and of course powered by unmatched Intel offerings.

I've been watching Intc since they announced their focus on mobile chip, and they seem to be on time, successful in R&D and development and now getting first major pierce into the market. The only wish I had was to stay on course when it was $19; on the other hand, I feel a lot more safe/confident with the investment now actually.

Message.Title: Intel Investors Boost Stock On Mobile Win, Upgrade
Message.Msg: Intel investors are on a honeymoon with new CEO Brian Krzanich. On Monday, they celebrated a big customer win for its mobile chips and a new generation of PC processors. Intel shares rose 4% Monday to 25.24. The stock broke out of a long cup-with-handle base, passing a 24.67 buy point. Intel's latest boost came from announcements at the Computex conference in Taiwan. There, Samsung Electronics revealed on Monday that it will use Intel processors to power a new version of one of its main Android tablets. These Samsung Galaxy Tabs tablets from last year use ARM chips, but its newest Tabs will use Intel chips. The deal marks Intel's first tier-one tablet design win. Samsung will use Intel's 1.6-gigahertz dual-core processor in its 10.1-inch Galaxy Tab 3 tablet, which will compete with Apple's (AAPL) iPad. The new tablet will be available worldwide later this month. Fits Samsung's Playbook "Samsung's decision to begin using Intel in a marquee Android device is a coup for the U.S. chipmaker as it races to establish itself in a mobile market it was slow initially to recognize and invest in," Benchmark analyst Gary Mobley said in a research note Monday. From Investor's Business Daily

Message.Title: Intel given better odds against ARM as Taiwan show kicks off
Message.Msg: ... things are looking up for Intel, analysts say, citing new products expected to be unveiled at Computex. Intel shares were up 4% Monday, the top gainer on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, after FBR Capital upgraded the stock to outperform. “On the eve of Computex and the public debut for ‘Haswell,’ we acknowledge the challenges ahead for Intel in the PC market, but now believe the company has added more than enough new avenues of growth to replace lost PC units,” analyst Christopher Rolland wrote. Haswell is the codename for Intel’s core chip for PCs. That market is shrinking fast, but analysts see Intel using its enormous advantage in manufacturing technology to emerge as a stronger player in the fast-growing mobile arena. The company is also expected to roll out a new version of its Atom chip geared to mobile devices. “We argue that Intel’s business plan is not based on PC or server, but rather on executing according to Moore’s Law,” Rolland wrote. He was referring to the industry trend named after Intel co-founder Gordon Moore, in which the number of transistors that companies have been able put on an integrated circuit has roughly doubled every two years. This trend has allowed chip makers to make smaller, more powerful, and less expensive processors. Intel is widely seen as turning that advantage into catching up with ARM-based chips on the power front. And it seems to be working, says Bernstein Research analyst Stacy Rasgon. “They seem to be turning sentiment,” he told MarketWatch. “Intel’s products look very, very good. It’s no longer the case that you say Intel is not competitive on power. They’re very competitive.” From MarketWatch

Message.Title: Intel given big break in mobile chips challenge
Message.Msg: The move will provide an early boost for new Intel chief executive Brian Krzanich, who took the helm last month. Mr Krzanich admitted to shareholders that “we were slow to the mobile market” and promised aggressive action to address this error. As mobile devices have eaten away at the market for personal computers, where Intel is dominant, the US company has come under pressure to develop a strong presence in the market for mobile application processors, but it has made little progress so far partly because until recently Arm-based chips were far more energy-efficient than those designed by Intel. Jasmeet Chadha, an analyst at Sanford C Bernstein, said that the contract was the single most important to date in Intel’s mobile business. “Their previous wins have been from second- or third-tier players such as [Chinese phonemakers] ZTE or Lenovo,” he said. Sector sales figures in the first quarter of this year demonstrated the urgency of the challenge facing Intel. Unit sales of tablets rose by an annual 282 per cent, and those of smartphones by 41.6 per cent, according to the research group IDC. By contrast, sales of personal computers declined 27 per cent. But its deal with Samsung reflects the progress Intel has made in reducing the power consumption of its chips, representing a growing threat to its FTSE 100 rival. Shares in Arm fell 7 per cent in London on Monday. From The Financial Times

Message.Title: Uh Oh... ASUS Transformer Android and Windows
Message.Msg: ASUS Transformer Book Trio runs Android and Windows on lap, desk & in hands Chris Davies, Jun 3rd 2013 Discuss [1] A good notebook can’t just do one thing well these days, it has to multi-task in at least two ways, and so on that front the ASUS Transformer Book Trio is off to a good start. Revealed at Computex 2013 this morning, the 11.6-inch notebook is billed as “the world’s first three-in-one mobile device” with a removable screen section that can flip between Windows 8 and Android, and which can be used both on the desktop and while mobile.

Topic.Title: Uh Oh... ASUS Transformer Android and Windows

Message.Msg: In ultrabook mode, the Transformer Book Trio is a compact ultraportable with a full keyboard and a 1080p HD display. However, it can also be pulled from the keyboard to make an Android tablet, or slotted into a PC Station dock for desktop use. In the slate section itself, there’s a 2.0GHz Intel Atom Z2580 processor and up to 64GB of storage: that can run either Windows 8 or Android 4.2 Jelly Bean, depending on which mode you switch between. There’s a dedicated key to hop between the platforms, and ASUS says that users should not only be able to access data from the other OS, but stay on the same webpage they’re currently viewing.

Topic.Title: Uh Oh... ASUS Transformer Android and Windows

Message.Msg: The PC Station gets its own, dedicated processor, however: a 4th-gen Intel Core i7 no less. There’s also a 750GB hard-drive, and connectivity for an external display if 11.6-inches isn’t quite your ergonomic ideal for desk-bound operations. The dock recharges the slate section’s battery, too. ASUS hasn’t confirmed pricing for the Transformer Book Trio, though it’s expected to reach the market sometime in Q3 2013. Whether there are sufficient buyers intrigued enough in a twin-OS hybrid that can only really be used by one person at a time (unlike, say, an ultrabook and a separate Android tablet) remains to be seen.
